channel.title: JaneBytes Cybersecurity Feed
channel.description: Summarized articles from top cybersecurity sources.

item.title: Webinar: What the Next Wave of AI Cyberattacks Will Look Like — And How to Survive
item.description: Attackers are evolving with AI, gaining new tools such as deepfake scams, bots that bypass human review, and synthetic identities. The fight is no longer just at the network's edge, but also at the login screen. Legacy security models can't keep up with AI-powered threats, making identity the last line of defense.

item.title: Microsoft August 2025 Patch Tuesday Fixes Kerberos Zero-Day Among 111 Total New Flaws
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53779 (CVSS score: 7.2), CVE-2025-53766 (CVSS score: 9.8), CVE-2025-50165 (CVSS score: 9.8), CVE-2025-53792 (CVSS score: 9.1), CVE-2025-53787 (CVSS score: 8.2), CVE-2025-50177 (CVSS score: 8.1), CVE-2025-50176 (CVSS score: 7.8); Summary: A publicly disclosed zero-day privilege escalation vulnerability in Windows Kerberos allows an attacker to compromise an Active Directory domain by misusing delegated Managed Service Account objects, requiring pre-existing control of two attributes of the dMSA; other vulnerabilities include remote code execution and information disclosure defects.

item.title: New Charon Ransomware Uses DLL Sideloading and Anti-EDR Tactics in Targeted Attacks
item.description: The article discusses a novel ransomware family called Charon, deployed in a sophisticated campaign targeting the public sector and aviation industry in the Middle East. The malware employs advanced persistent threat (APT)-style techniques, including DLL sideloading, process injection, and multilayered payloads to evade endpoint security and encrypt files.

item.title: Malicious npm Package Lures Job Seekers and Exfiltrates Sensitive Data
item.description: Vulnerable Product: EvaCodes-Community/UltraX; CVE(s): None; Summary: The EvaCodes-Community/UltraX GitHub repository contains a malicious Trojanized npm package, rtk-logger@1.11.5, which steals sensitive data such as login credentials, encryption keys, and certificates from browsers like Chrome, Brave, Opera, and Firefox. The package also executes additional payloads, including remote command execution, environment detection, and logging.

item.title: Chrome Security Update Fixes High-Severity Flaws Allowing Arbitrary Code Execution
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chrome; CVE(s): CVE-2025-8879, CVE-2025-8880, CVE-2025-8901; Summary: The update addresses six security vulnerabilities, including three high-severity flaws that could allow arbitrary code execution. The most critical vulnerability is a heap buffer overflow in the media codec library, while another vulnerability is a race condition in the V8 JavaScript engine.

item.title: Charon Ransomware Hits Middle East Sectors Using APT-Level Evasion Tactics
item.description: This article reports on a new ransomware family called Charon that targets the Middle East's public sector and aviation industry. The threat actor uses DLL side-loading, process injection, and evasion techniques to avoid detection by endpoint detection and response (EDR) software.

item.title: FortiWeb Authentication Bypass Vulnerability Allows Logins as Any Existing User
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Fortinet FortiWeb; CVE(s): CVE-2025-52970; Summary: A critical vulnerability in FortiWeb's cookie parsing mechanism allows unauthenticated attackers to bypass authentication and impersonate any existing user, exploiting an out-of-bounds read access issue to force the server to use a predictable, all-zero secret key for session encryption and signing.

item.title: Critical FortiSIEM Vulnerability Allows Attackers to Execute Malicious Commands, PoC Found in the Wild
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Fortinet; CVE(s): CVE-2025-25256; Summary: A critical vulnerability in Fortinet's FortiSIEM platform allows remote attackers to execute unauthorized commands without authentication, with a maximum CVSS score of 9.8 and practical exploit code circulating in the wild. The flaw enables OS command injection, granting attackers control over the SIEM infrastructure, potentially allowing manipulation of security logs or disabling monitoring capabilities.

item.title: New Zero-Click NTLM Credential Leak Exploit Bypasses Microsoft Patch for CVE-2025-24054
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft; CVE(s): CVE-2025-50154; Summary: A zero-click NTLM credential leakage vulnerability allows attackers to extract NTLMv2-SSP hashes without user interaction on fully patched Windows systems. The exploit bypasses Microsoft's previous patch for CVE-2025-24054 by manipulating Windows shortcut files and exploiting how the explorer.exe process handles remote binary retrieval, posing risks for organizations relying solely on Microsoft's previous patch for protection against NTLM credential leakage.

item.title: Microsoft Teams RCE Flaw Allows Hackers to Read, Modify, and Delete Messages
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Teams; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53783; Summary: A critical remote code execution vulnerability in Microsoft Teams allows attackers to execute malicious code and potentially access, modify, or delete user messages. The vulnerability requires no special privileges but necessitates user interaction, making exploitation less likely due to high attack complexity.

item.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, August 2025 Edition
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53786, CVE-2025-53779, CVE-2025-53766, CVE-2025-50165, CVE-2025-53733, CVE-2025-53778; Summary: Multiple critical vulnerabilities in Windows operating systems and software were fixed by Microsoft, including a vulnerability that allows an attacker to pivot from a compromised Exchange Server into an organization's cloud environment (CVE-2025-53786), a weakness in the Windows Kerberos authentication system that grants domain administrator privileges (CVE-2025-53779), and remote code execution bugs in the Windows GDI+ component and Microsoft Word.

item.title: Claude gets 1M tokens support via API to take on Gemini 2.5 Pro
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: None; Summary: This article is not about a vulnerability, but rather an upgrade to the Claude Sonnet 4 API, which now supports remembering up to 1 million tokens of context. The increased limit enables users to build better apps and analyze more data at once.
FYSA: None

item.title: Hackers leak Allianz Life data stolen in Salesforce attacks
item.description: The ShinyHunters extortion group has released stolen data belonging to US insurance giant Allianz Life, exposing 2.8 million records with sensitive information on business partners and customers. The attack is part of a wave of Salesforce-targeted thefts carried out by the group, which has also claimed responsibility for attacks on Internet Archive, Pearson, Coinbase, and others.

item.title: OpenAI rolls out Gmail, Calendar, and Contacts integration in ChatGPT
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: None; Summary: This article is not about a vulnerability. It discusses OpenAI's plans to integrate Google services (Gmail, Google Calendar, and Google Contacts) with ChatGPT, allowing users to access information from these tools in their conversations. The integration aims to enhance the chat experience by providing faster and easier access to relevant information.
Note: There is no mention of a vulnerability or a cybersecurity-related issue in this article.

item.title: ChatGPT's new subscription costs less than $5, but it's not for everyone
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; FYSA: The article discusses OpenAI's introduction of a new pricing plan called "ChatGPT Go" aimed at developing countries, including India. It also mentions Google exploring a similar low-tier subscription for Gemini, likely limited to certain regions.

item.title: Muddled Libra’s Strike Teams: Amalgamated Evil
item.description: Muddled Libra is a loose collaboration of cybercriminals with common interests, not an organized entity; the group's fluid nature makes it challenging to track and predict targets; defenders should focus on protecting valuable data and assets rather than predicting specific industries or tactics.

item.title: Malvertising campaign leads to PS1Bot, a multi-stage malware framework
item.description:
FYSA:
The provided article describes an in-depth analysis of a malware campaign that utilizes PowerShell modules to deliver malicious payloads to infected systems. The malware family, referred to as PS1Bot, demonstrates various techniques to evade detection and maintain persistence on the compromised system.
Key findings from the analysis include:
1. The use of PowerShell as a primary vector for delivering malicious payloads. 2. The implementation of multiple modules with distinct functionalities, such as screen capture, keylogging, clipboard capture, and system surveying. 3. The employment of runtime compilation to create and execute PowerShell scripts. 4. The use of mutex handling and sleep periods to evade detection by security products. 5. The similarity in design architecture and functionality between PS1Bot and another malware family, AHK Bot.
To detect and block this threat, the article recommends utilizing various Cisco Secure products, including:
* Cisco Secure Endpoint (formerly AMP for Endpoints) * Cisco Secure Email (formerly Cisco Email Security) * Cisco Secure Firewall (former Next-Generation Firewall and Firepower NGFW) appliances * Cisco Secure Network/Cloud Analytics (Stealthwatch/Stealthwatch Cloud) * Cisco Secure Malware Analytics (Threat Grid) * Cisco Secure Access * Umbrella, Cisco's secure internet gateway (SIG)
Additionally, the article provides Snort SIDs for the threats and ClamAV detections.

item.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday for August 2025 — Snort rules and prominent vulnerabilities
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft; CVE(s): CVE-2025-50176, CVE-2025-50177, CVE-2025-53778, CVE-2025-53781, CVE-2025-53733, CVE-2025-53740, CVE-2025-53766, CVE-2025-50165, CVE-2025-49707, CVE-2025-48807, CVE-2025-53731, CVE-2025-53784, CVE-2025-53793; Summary: Microsoft has released a security update with 111 vulnerabilities affecting various products, including Windows services and applications. The vulnerabilities include remote code execution (RCE), elevation of privilege, and information disclosure vulnerabilities.

item.title: Law Enforcement Seizes BlackSuit Ransomware Servers Targeting U.S. Critical Infrastructure
item.description: The U.S. Department of Justice and international law enforcement agencies collaborated to seize critical infrastructure associated with the BlackSuit ransomware group, including command-and-control servers and domains used for deploying ransomware payloads, extorting victims, and laundering illicit proceeds. The operation targeted the group's backend infrastructure, which enabled initial access via phishing campaigns, RDP exploitation, and vulnerability chaining, as well as data exfiltration prior to encryption.

item.title: Docker Hub still hosts dozens of Linux images with the XZ backdoor
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Various Linux distributions (Debian, Fedora, OpenSUSE, and Red Hat); CVE(s): CVE-2024-3094; Summary: The XZ-Utils backdoor, discovered in March 2024, was malicious code hidden in the liblzma.so library of the xz-utils compression tool, versions 5.6.0 and 5.6.1. It allowed attackers to bypass authentication and remotely run commands as root via SSH. Despite being reported earlier, at least 35 Linux images on Docker Hub still contain the backdoor, making users and organizations vulnerable.

item.title: Researchers Spot XZ Utils Backdoor in Dozens of Docker Hub Images, Fueling Supply Chain Risks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: XZ Utils; CVE(s): CVE-2024-3094; Summary: The XZ Utils backdoor allows unauthorized remote access and execution of arbitrary payloads through SSH. It was discovered in versions 5.6.0 and 5.6.1, and can be triggered when a client interacts with the infected SSH server. The backdoor uses glibc's IFUNC mechanism to bypass authentication and execute root commands remotely.

item.title: Electronic Arts Blocks 300,000 Cheating Attempts After Battlefield 6 Beta Launch
item.description: This article discusses the success of Electronic Arts' Javelin anti-cheat technology in preventing over 330,000 attempts to cheat or tamper with security controls during the Battlefield 6 Open Beta Early Access launch. The technology uses Secure Boot to ensure the integrity of the operating system and loaded drivers, detecting potential integrity breaches and enabling automated bans or further forensic analysis.

item.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday August 2025: 107 Vulnerabilities Patched, Including 35 RCE Flaws
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft; CVE(s): CVE-2025-50165, CVE-2025-53766, CVE-2025-53781, CVE-2025-48807, etc. (107 total); Summary: Microsoft has released August 2025 Patch Tuesday fixes addressing 107 vulnerabilities across its ecosystem, including 35 remote code execution bugs that could allow attackers to run malicious code on affected systems. The patches cover a range of products and services, including Windows, Office, Exchange Server, Azure, and more.

item.title: Microsoft August 2025 Patch Tuesday fixes one zero-day, 107 flaws
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows Kerberos; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5377; Summary: A publicly disclosed zero-day vulnerability in Windows Kerberos allows an authenticated attacker to gain domain administrator privileges by exploiting a relative path traversal flaw. The vulnerability requires elevated access to specific dMSA attributes, making it a complex attack vector.

item.title: Windows 11 KB5063878 & KB5063875 cumulative updates released
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability, but rather an announcement from Microsoft regarding cumulative updates and new features in Windows 11. It describes various improvements, including AI-powered features, a more streamlined interface for unexpected restarts, and bug fixes for File Explorer, Start menu, and Notifications.

item.title: Windows 10 KB5063709 update fixes extended security updates enrollment
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows 10; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article discusses the release of the KB5063709 cumulative update for Windows 10 22H2 and Windows 10 21H2, which includes seven fixes or changes, including a fix for a bug that prevented enrollment in extended security updates.

item.title: Fortinet SSL VPNs Hit by Global Brute-Force Wave Before Attackers Shift to FortiManager
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Fortinet; CVE(s): None; Summary: Brute-force traffic aimed at Fortinet SSL VPN devices has been observed, with over 780 unique IP addresses participating in the effort. The targets include the United States, Hong Kong, Brazil, Spain, and Japan. The activity suggests deliberate and precise targeting of Fortinet's SSL VPNs.

item.title: Cybercrime Groups ShinyHunters, Scattered Spider Join Forces in Extortion Attacks on Businesses
item.description: The article discusses an ongoing data extortion campaign targeting Salesforce customers, attributed to ShinyHunters and Scattered Spider. The two groups appear to be working together, using tactics such as vishing and social engineering attacks. The campaign is targeting major corporations and financial services companies globally, with a focus on high-profile companies across various industry verticals.

item.title: US govt seizes $1 million in crypto from BlackSuit ransomware gang
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability, but rather reports on law enforcement efforts to combat ransomware attacks. The U.S. Department of Justice and other agencies seized cryptocurrency and digital assets worth $1,091,453 from the BlackSuit ransomware gang and $2.4 million from a Chaos ransomware group member, highlighting the importance of disrupting cybercriminals' financial infrastructure.

item.title: Android's pKVM hypervisor earns SESIP Level 5 security certification
item.description: The article discusses Google's protected Kernel-based Virtual Machine (pKVM) for Android achieving SESIP Level 5 certification, the highest security assurance level for IoT and mobile platforms. The pKVM provides an isolated environment for executing critical workloads, including AI models and biometric authentication.

item.title: Curly COMrades cyberspies hit govt orgs with custom malware
item.description: The article describes a new cyber-espionage threat group, tracked as Curly COMrades, which uses a custom backdoor malware called MucorAgent. The malware provides persistent access through seemingly inactive scheduled tasks and has been used to target government and judicial bodies in Georgia, energy firms in Moldova, and other organizations that support Russian interests.

item.title: Over 3,000 NetScaler devices left unpatched against CitrixBleed 2 bug
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Citrix NetScaler; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5777, CVE-2025-6543; Summary: Over 3,300 unpatched Citrix NetScaler devices remain vulnerable to a critical vulnerability that allows attackers to bypass authentication and access sensitive data. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-5777, can be exploited to steal session tokens, credentials, and other sensitive data. Additionally, the same devices are also vulnerable to another critical vulnerability, CVE-2025-6543, which has been actively exploited in denial-of-service attacks.

item.title: 275M patient records breached—How to meet HIPAA password manager requirements
item.description: The article highlights the importance of password management in healthcare, citing that over 700 data breach incidents occurred in the sector in 2024, exposing over 275 million patient records. It emphasizes that compromised credentials are a primary attack vector and notes that HIPAA violations can result in significant penalties, reputational damage, and permanent listing on OCR's "Wall of Shame" breach portal. The article also stresses the need for healthcare organizations to prioritize password management as a critical component of both compliance and patient safety.

item.title: Windows 11 23H2 Home and Pro reach end of support in November
item.description: The article announces the end-of-service date for certain versions of Windows 11, including Home and Pro editions. It also notes the increasing adoption rate of Windows 11, surpassing Windows 10's install base. Additionally, it mentions a trend in password cracking, with nearly half of environments having passwords cracked in July 2025.

item.title: New ‘Curly COMrades’ APT Using NGEN COM Hijacking in Georgia, Moldova Attacks
item.description: Curly COMrades is a previously undocumented threat actor that targets entities in Georgia and Moldova with a cyber espionage campaign to facilitate long-term access to target networks. The group uses legitimate tools, such as Resocks, SSH, and Stunnel, to create multiple conduits into internal networks and steal credentials.

item.title: Schneider Electric EcoStruxure Power Monitoring Expert
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Schneider Electric EcoStruxure Power Monitoring Expert; CVE(s): CVE-2025-54923, CVE-2025-54924, CVE-2025-54925, CVE-2025-54926, and CVE-2025-54927; Summary: The Schneider Electric EcoStruxure Power Monitoring Expert contains multiple vulnerabilities including path traversal, deserialization of untrusted data, and server-side request forgery. Successful exploitation could allow a remote attacker to read arbitrary files, access internal services directly, or execute malicious code.

item.title: Ashlar-Vellum Cobalt, Xenon, Argon, Lithium, Cobalt Share
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Ashlar-Vellum (Cobalt, Xenon, Argon, Lithium, Cobalt Share); CVE(s): CVE-2025-53705, CVE-2025-41392, CVE-2025-52584, CVE-2025-46269; Summary: The affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing CO, AR, XE, and VC6 files, leading to out-of-bounds write, out-of-bounds read, and heap-based buffer overflow vulnerabilities. Successful exploitation could allow an attacker to disclose information and execute arbitrary code in the context of the current process.

item.title: CISA Adds Three Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Internet Explorer, Microsoft Office Excel, RARLAB WinRAR; CVE(s): CVE-2013-3893, CVE-2007-0671, CVE-2025-8088; Summary: These three vulnerabilities have been added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog due to evidence of active exploitation. The vulnerabilities are frequent attack vectors for malicious cyber actors and pose significant risks to the federal enterprise and other organizations that fail to remediate them in a timely manner.

item.title: AVEVA PI Integrator
item.description: Vulnerable Product: AVEVA PI Integrator; CVE(s): CVE-2025-54460, CVE-2025-41415; Summary: Unrestricted file upload and insertion of sensitive information into sent data vulnerabilities in PI Integrator for Business Analytics versions 2020 R2 SP1 and prior allow authenticated attackers to disclose sensitive information or execute files.

item.title: Santesoft Sante PACS Server
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Santesoft, Sante PACS Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-0572, CVE-2025-53948, CVE-2025-54156, CVE-2025-54862, CVE-2025-54759; Summary: The Sante PACS Server is vulnerable to path traversal, double free, cleartext transmission of sensitive information, and cross-site scripting. Successful exploitation could allow an attacker to create arbitrary files, cause a denial-of-service condition, obtain sensitive information, and steal a user's cookie information.

item.title: Johnson Controls iSTAR Ultra, iSTAR Ultra SE, iSTAR Ultra G2, iSTAR Ultra G2 SE, iSTAR Edge G2
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Johnson Controls iSTAR Ultra, iSTAR Ultra SE, iSTAR Ultra G2, iSTAR Ultra G2 SE, iSTAR Edge G2; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53695, CVE-2025-53696, CVE-2025-53697, CVE-2025-53698, CVE-2025-53699, CVE-2025-53700; Summary: Multiple vulnerabilities were discovered in Johnson Controls iSTAR Ultra and Edge door controllers, including OS command injection, insufficient verification of data authenticity, use of default credentials, missing protection mechanism for alternate hardware interface, and insecure storage of sensitive information. Successful exploitation may allow an attacker to modify firmware and access protected space.

item.title: CISA Releases Seven Industrial Control Systems Advisories
item.description: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) released seven Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories on August 12, 2025. These advisories provide information about current security issues, vulnerabilities, and exploits surrounding ICS products from various vendors, including Ashlar-Vellum Cobalt, Johnson Controls, Schneider Electric, AVEVA, MegaSys Computer Technologies, and Santesoft. The advisories aim to help users and administrators review technical details and mitigations for the identified issues.

item.title: The Ultimate Battle: Enterprise Browsers vs. Secure Browser Extensions
item.description: The article compares two approaches to addressing security gaps in browsers: Enterprise Browsers and Enterprise Browser Extensions. It highlights the pros and cons of each, including control, enforcement, integration, and operations. The guide is designed to help security teams make an informed decision about which approach best fits their environment and risk profile.

item.title: Dutch NCSC Confirms Active Exploitation of Citrix NetScaler CVE-2025-6543 in Critical Sectors
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Citrix; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6543; Summary: A critical security vulnerability (CVE-2025-6543) in Citrix NetScaler ADC products allows for unintended control flow and denial-of-service when devices are configured as a Gateway or AAA virtual server. The vulnerability was exploited as a zero-day since early May 2025, two months before its public disclosure, with malicious web shells found on compromised devices.

item.title: High-severity WinRAR 0-day exploited for weeks by 2 groups
item.description: Vulnerable Product: WinRAR; CVE(s): None; Summary: A vulnerability in WinRAR allowed attackers to install malware on infected systems. The vulnerability was exploited through archives attached to emails impersonating employees of the All-Russian Research Institute. Two execution chains were observed, one delivering a malicious DLL file and another running a Windows executable to deliver a final payload installing SnipBot, a known piece of RomCom malware.

item.title: New TETRA Radio Encryption Flaws Expose Law Enforcement Communications
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Terrestrial Trunked Radio (TETRA); CVE(s): CVE-2025-52940, CVE-2025-52941, CVE-2025-52942, CVE-2025-52943, CVE-2025-52944; Summary: The TETRA protocol has several security issues, including replay and brute-force attacks on its end-to-end encryption (E2EE) mechanism. Additionally, packet injection attacks can be used to intercept radio communications and inject malicious data traffic.

item.title: Researchers Spot Surge in Erlang/OTP SSH RCE Exploits, 70% Target OT Firewalls
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Erlang/Open Telecom Platform (OTP); CVE(s): CVE-2025-32433; Summary: A missing authentication issue allows attackers with network access to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable systems without requiring credentials, posing a severe risk. The flaw was patched in April 2025, and it has been observed being exploited since early May 2025, primarily targeting OT networks in industries such as healthcare, agriculture, media, and entertainment.

item.title: Salesforce-Related Data Breach Affecting Multiple Companies
item.description:
FYSA:
The article discusses a series of coordinated intrusions targeting multiple high-profile companies across various sectors, attributed to ShinyHunters. The attackers relied on social engineering, voice phishing, and abuse of Salesforce's Connected Apps feature to gain access to sensitive customer data. The breach did not exploit any vulnerability in Salesforce itself but rather manipulated end users and took advantage of misconfigured or overly permissive third-party app settings.

item.title: CVE-2025-8088: WinRAR Zero-Day Exploited in Targeted Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: WinRAR; CVE(s): CVE-2025-8088; Summary: A zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2025-8088) in Windows versions of WinRAR, affecting UnRAR.dll and its portable source code, allows attackers to trick the tool into extracting files outside the user's intended directory. This can deposit malicious files in sensitive system locations, which execute automatically on login. The flaw has been actively exploited by Russia-aligned hacking group RomCom since July 18, 2025, and was fixed with the release of WinRAR 7.13 on July 30, 2025.

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: BadCam Attack, WinRAR 0-Day, EDR Killer, NVIDIA Flaws, Ransomware Attacks & More
item.description: The article appears to be a collection of various cybersecurity-related news and updates, covering topics such as ransomware attacks, malware campaigns, phishing schemes, and security product releases. It does not specifically discuss a vulnerability in a software, hardware, or firmware product.

item.title: What Is Agentic Threat Intelligence (ATI)?
item.description: This article discusses Agentic Threat Intelligence (ATI), which uses autonomous agents to analyze and respond to emerging threats. ATI systems can correlate Indicators of Compromise (IOCs), contextualize threat data, and recommend or initiate mitigation steps. The article highlights the advantages of ATI over traditional threat intelligence platforms, including its ability to adapt to novel attacks and ambiguous indicators.

item.title: 6 Lessons Learned: Focusing Security Where Business Value Lives
item.description: The article discusses the importance of aligning security efforts with business priorities to achieve better security outcomes and more efficient operations. It presents a 4-step methodology for identifying and securing business-critical assets, including identifying critical business processes, mapping those processes to technology, prioritizing based on business risk, and taking action to remediate exposures. The article highlights the need for CISOs to bridge the gap between technical findings and executive leadership, emphasizing the importance of framing security in terms of business risk management to gain support from financial leadership.

item.title: Keys to the Kingdom: Erlang/OTP SSH Vulnerability Analysis and Exploits Observed in the Wild
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Erlang/OTP; CVE(s): CVE-2025-32433; Summary: This vulnerability allows unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) in the Secure Shell (SSH) daemon (sshd) from certain versions of the Erlang programming language's Open Telecom Platform (OTP). The failure to reject post-authentication messages before authentication completion creates a significant attack surface that is being exploited in the wild.

item.title: E-Commerce Platforms Face Rising Dark Web Threats; Admin Access and Customer Data on Sale
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article reports on a growing trend of cybercriminal activity targeting global e-commerce businesses, including unauthorized admin access, leaked customer databases, and zero-day exploits. Threat actors are advertising these vulnerabilities and exploits for sale on the dark web, posing significant risks to online retailers and their customers.
(Note: There is no specific vulnerability mentioned in the article, but rather a trend of cybercriminal activity targeting e-commerce businesses.)

item.title: WinRAR Zero-Day Under Active Exploitation – Update to Latest Version Immediately
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Ilya Korchun (WinRAR); CVE(s): CVE-2025-8088; Summary: A zero-day vulnerability in WinRAR tracked as CVE-2025-8088 allows for arbitrary code execution by crafting malicious archive files. The issue affects Windows versions of WinRAR, RAR, UnRAR, portable UnRAR source code, and UnRAR.dll up to and including version 7.12, which has been addressed in version 7.13 released on July 30, 2025.

item.title: New Win-DDoS Flaws Let Attackers Turn Public Domain Controllers into DDoS Botnet via RPC, LDAP
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows; CVE(s): CVE-2025-26673, CVE-2025-32724, CVE-2025-49716, CVE-2025-49722; Summary: A novel attack technique called Win-DDoS allows an attacker to manipulate public domain controllers (DCs) to create a malicious botnet for conducting powerful DDoS attacks. The attack can be triggered by sending RPC calls to DCs, which then send CLDAP requests to the attacker's server, leading to a referral response that refers the DCs to the attacker's LDAP server. This can cause a denial-of-service (DoS) attack on the target system without requiring code execution or credentials.

item.title: Researchers Detail Windows EPM Poisoning Exploit Chain Leading to Domain Privilege Escalation
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49760; Summary: The vulnerability in Microsoft's Windows Remote Procedure Call (RPC) communication protocol allows an authorized attacker to perform spoofing attacks and impersonate a known server. The attack, called EPM poisoning, enables unprivileged users to pose as a legitimate service with the goal of coercing a protected process to authenticate against an arbitrary server chosen by the attacker.

item.title: Linux-Based Lenovo Webcams’ Flaw Can Be Remotely Exploited for BadUSB Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Lenovo; CVE(s): CVE-2025-4371; Summary: The vulnerabilities in select Lenovo webcams allow remote attackers to inject keystrokes covertly and launch attacks independent of the host operating system. This could turn the webcams into BadUSB attack devices, which can be used to compromise computers and re-infect them even after a wipe and reinstall.

item.title: Researchers Reveal ReVault Attack Targeting Dell ControlVault3 Firmware in 100+ Laptop Models
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Dell ControlVault3 firmware; CVE(s): CVE-2025-25050, CVE-2025-25215, CVE-2025-24922, CVE-2025-24311, CVE-2025-24919; Summary: Multiple security flaws in Dell's ControlVault3 firmware and Windows APIs allow attackers to bypass Windows login, extract cryptographic keys, and maintain access after a fresh OS install by deploying malicious implants into the firmware. The vulnerabilities can be chained to escalate privileges, bypass authentication controls, and maintain persistence on compromised systems that survive operating system updates or reinstallations.

item.title: Researchers Uncover GPT-5 Jailbreak and Zero-Click AI Agent Attacks Exposing Cloud and IoT Systems
item.description: Vulnerable Product: OpenAI GPT-5; CVE(s): None; Summary: Researchers have discovered a jailbreak technique to bypass ethical guardrails in OpenAI's latest large language model (LLM) GPT-5 and produce illicit instructions. The technique, called Echo Chamber, uses narrative-driven steering to trick the model into generating undesirable responses.

item.title: ReVault! When your SoC turns against you… deep dive edition
item.description:
The article appears to be a comprehensive analysis of vulnerabilities and security risks in ControlVault devices, which are used for fingerprint recognition and authentication purposes. The analysis covers multiple vulnerabilities, including heap corruption, stack overflow, out-of-bound read, and out-of-bound write issues, as well as the potential consequences of exploiting these vulnerabilities.
The article also discusses how an attacker could leverage code execution in the firmware to compromise the device's host system. Specifically, it highlights how an attacker could modify the firmware to make Windows Hello accept any fingerprint, potentially leading to unauthorized access to devices and systems.
Furthermore, the analysis shows how an attacker could use the modified firmware to leak key material from the OTP memory of the Broadcom chip, allowing them to decrypt or forge SCD blobs. This could enable the creation of custom firmware that can be used to compromise device security.
In summary, this article provides a detailed analysis of vulnerabilities and potential attack vectors in ControlVault devices, highlighting the importance of robust security measures to prevent exploitation.

item.title: Encryption made for police and military radios may be easily cracked
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Sepura; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article discusses a vulnerability in Sepura radios, specifically the use of reduced key lengths (128, 64, or 56 bit) for encryption, which may not be transparently communicated to end users. This could potentially weaken the encryption system and compromise government communications that rely on end-to-end encryption.

item.title: CyberArk and HashiCorp Flaws Enable Remote Vault Takeover Without Credentials
item.description: Vulnerable Product: CyberArk Secrets Manager and Self-Hosted, HashiCorp Vault; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49827, CVE-2025-49831, CVE-2025-49828, CVE-2025-6000, CVE-2025-5999, CVE-2025-6037; Summary: The vulnerabilities in CyberArk Secrets Manager and Self-Hosted, and HashiCorp Vault allow remote attackers to bypass authentication, escalate privileges, execute arbitrary code, steal enterprise secrets, and extract tokens. The most severe issues include remote code execution (CVE-2025-49828) and arbitrary remote code execution via plugin catalog abuse (CVE-2025-6000).

item.title: KrebsOnSecurity in New ‘Most Wanted’ HBO Max Series
item.description: The article features a documentary series about cybercrime on HBO Max, which includes interviews with a prolific Finnish hacker, Julius Kivimäki, who was convicted of leaking patient records from an online psychotherapy practice while attempting to extort the clinic and its patients. The documentary explores Kivimäki's criminal career, including his involvement in distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, swatting, and extortion attempts.

item.title: Adult sites are stashing exploit code inside racy .svg files
item.description: Malicious actors are exploiting .svg format files on WordPress-based porn sites to hijack Facebook likes without user consent, inducing browsers to like specific posts. This attack requires the target's Facebook account to be open and logged in. The script downloads additional obfuscated JavaScript and ultimately loads Trojan.JS.Likejack, which silently clicks a "Like" button for a specified Facebook page.

item.title: AI Tools Fuel Brazilian Phishing Scam While Efimer Trojan Steals Crypto from 5,000 Victims
item.description:
A new phishing campaign is using legitimate generative AI-powered website building tools to create replica phishing pages mimicking Brazilian government agencies. The campaign targets unsuspecting users, tricking them into making unwarranted payments through the country's PIX payment system, and aims to collect sensitive personal information, including CPF numbers.
FYSA: Threat actors are using legitimate AI-powered website building tools to create phishing pages that mimic Brazilian government agencies, targeting unsuspecting users with financially motivated attacks. The campaign also employs staged data collection, API validation, and other tactics to increase the legitimacy of the attack.

item.title: Dark Web Profile: Interlock Ransomware
item.description: Interlock is a ransomware group that has been active since late 2024 and targets critical infrastructure, healthcare, education, manufacturing, government, finance, and technology sectors. The group uses advanced social engineering tactics, such as ClickFix and FileFix, to trick users into running malicious PowerShell commands. They also use double extortion, stealing data before encryption and threatening to leak it if the victim does not pay the ransom.

item.title: What Makes the Deep Web a Valuable Threat Intelligence Source
item.description: The article discusses the value of the deep web as a source of threat intelligence, highlighting its potential to provide early warnings, credential exposures, and covert threat actor activity that often go unnoticed by surface-level monitoring. It also emphasizes the importance of combining deep web insights with other intelligence sources and leveraging tools that provide real-time enrichment, while relying on skilled analysts to interpret and act on the data.

item.title: CVE-2025-53786: CISA Issues Emergency Directive for Critical Microsoft Exchange Hybrid Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53786; Summary: The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-53786, is an Elevation of Privilege flaw in hybrid Microsoft Exchange Server configurations. It allows attackers to escalate privileges from on-premises environments into connected cloud services, potentially compromising the organization's entire Exchange Online environment.

item.title: What Is Deep Web Threat Intelligence?
item.description: The article discusses the importance of threat intelligence from the deep web, which is often misunderstood as being equivalent to the dark web. It highlights that the deep web is a hidden layer of the internet that contains valuable information for threat detection and response efforts. The article explains the differences between the surface web, deep web, and dark web, and how incorporating deep web intelligence into security operations can enhance visibility and speed up incident response.

item.title: Leaked Credentials Up 160%: What Attackers Are Doing With Them
item.description: Leaked credentials accounted for 22% of breaches in 2024, with a 160% increase in leaked credentials in 2025 compared to the previous year. The report highlights the growing trend of credential theft, automation making it easier, and the downstream effects of these leaks, including account takeover, credential stuffing, spam distribution, blackmail, and extortion.

item.title: RubyGems, PyPI Hit by Malicious Packages Stealing Credentials, Crypto, Forcing Security Changes
item.description: Vulnerable Product: RubyGems; CVE(s): None; Summary: A threat actor has published 60 malicious gems posing as automation tools for social media and messaging services, stealing credentials from unsuspecting users. The gems have been downloaded over 275,000 times since at least March 2023.

item.title: GreedyBear Steals $1M in Crypto Using 150+ Malicious Firefox Wallet Extensions
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Firefox; CVE(s): None; Summary: Over 150 malicious extensions were discovered in the Firefox marketplace, designed to impersonate popular cryptocurrency wallets and steal digital assets. The extensions used a technique called Extension Hollowing to bypass safeguards and exploit user trust.
FYSA: A campaign dubbed GreedyBear has leveraged these malicious extensions to steal over $1 million in digital assets. The threat actor also uses a C2 server to collect and manage stolen data, and may be targeting other browser marketplaces. Additionally, an AI-powered tool was used to create the malware distribution pipeline, indicating the group's ability to adapt tactics as needed.
FYSA: A separate cryptocurrency scam campaign has been flagged by SentinelOne, where a malicious smart contract is distributed disguised as a trading bot to drain user wallets. The scam uses AI-generated YouTube videos and aged accounts to build legitimacy, with over $900,000 in stolen profits reported so far.

item.title: Google discovered a new scam—and also fell victim to it
item.description: Google disclosed that its Salesforce instance was compromised by UNC6040, resulting in the retrieval of limited business information such as names and contact details. A second group, ShinyHunters, has engaged in extortion activities, potentially preparing to escalate tactics by launching a data leak site (DLS).

item.title: SocGholish Malware Spread via Ad Tools; Delivers Access to LockBit, Evil Corp, and Others
item.description: The article discusses the SocGholish malware, a JavaScript loader malware distributed via compromised websites and masquerading as deceptive updates for web browsers and software. It is attributed to TA569 (Gold Prelude, Mustard Tempest, Purple Vallhund, and UNC1543) and has been observed leveraging Traffic Distribution Systems (TDSs) like Parrot TDS and Keitaro TDS to filter and redirect users to sketchy content.

item.title: AI wrote my code and all I got was this broken prototype
item.description: This article discusses the use of AI in software development, specifically in identifying and resolving vulnerabilities. The author shares their personal experience with using an AI agent to write code for a project, highlighting both its benefits (e.g., generating boilerplate code) and limitations (e.g., failing to interface with required libraries).

item.title: Webinar: How to Stop Python Supply Chain Attacks—and the Expert Tools You Need
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: None; Summary: The article discusses the rising threat of malicious packages in the Python Package Index (PyPI), including attacks such as typo-squatting, repojacking, and slop-squatting. It highlights the importance of securing the Python supply chain to prevent attacks that can compromise code and cause real harm.
FYSA: The article describes a growing trend of malicious package uploads on PyPI, with attackers exploiting weak links in the open-source supply chain. It also mentions the need for visibility and control over what packages are installed, as well as the importance of using modern signing and provenance frameworks to trust code.

item.title: Malicious Go, npm Packages Deliver Cross-Platform Malware, Trigger Remote Data Wipes
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Various Go Packages; CVE(s): None; Summary: A set of 11 malicious Go packages has been discovered, which can download and execute additional payloads on Windows and Linux systems. The packages conceal an obfuscated loader that fetches second-stage ELF and PE binaries, allowing attackers to gather host information, access web browser data, and beacon out to their C2 server.
FYSA: A threat actor has been identified as the author of 11 malicious Go packages designed to download additional payloads from remote servers and execute them on both Windows and Linux systems. The packages were published on GitHub repositories and are part of a larger malware distribution channel in software supply chains, which can be used to steal sensitive information and target cryptocurrency wallets.
FYSA: Two npm packages masquerading as WhatsApp socket libraries have been discovered, which incorporate a phone number-based kill switch that can remotely wipe developers' systems. The packages were published by a user named "nayflore" in early July 2025 and have collectively been downloaded over 1,110 times.

item.title: CVE-2025-54948 & CVE-2025-54987: Trend Micro Apex One Exploited for RCE
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Trend Micro Apex One (on-premise); CVE(s): CVE-2025-54948, CVE-2025-54987; Summary: Two critical vulnerabilities allow unauthenticated attackers to execute remote code on unpatched systems, with one already observed in the wild. The flaws are command injection vulnerabilities found in the Trend Micro Apex One Management Console (on-premise) and target different CPU architectures.

item.title: Burk Technology ARC Solo
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Burk Technology ARC Solo; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5095; Summary: The ARC Solo monitoring and control device lacks authentication for its password change mechanism, allowing an attacker to take over the device without proper credentials. Successful exploitation could result in unauthorized access, locking out authorized users, or disrupting operations.

item.title: CISA Issues ED 25-02: Mitigate Microsoft Exchange Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Exchange Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53786; Summary: A vulnerability exists in Microsoft Exchange server hybrid deployments, presenting significant risk to organizations operating such configurations. The vulnerability must be mitigated by August 11, 2025, and CISA strongly encourages all organizations to address this issue.

item.title: CISA Releases Ten Industrial Control Systems Advisories
item.description: CISA released 10 Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories on August 7, 2025, providing timely information about current security issues, vulnerabilities, and exploits surrounding ICS. These advisories include multiple vendors and products, such as Delta Electronics, Johnson Controls, Rockwell Automation, and more.

item.title: Dreame Technology iOS and Android Mobile Applications
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Dreame Technology Dreamehome and MOVAhome mobile applications; CVE(s): CVE-2025-8393; Summary: The Dreamehome and MOVAhome mobile apps have a TLS vulnerability that allows man-in-the-middle attacks on untrusted networks, which could result in unauthorized information disclosure.

item.title: Delta Electronics DIAView
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Delta Electronics DIAView; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53417; Summary: The DIAView industrial automation management system is vulnerable to a path traversal vulnerability, allowing remote attackers to read or write files on the affected device. Successful exploitation may allow attackers to access sensitive information or disrupt operations.

item.title: Johnson Controls FX80 and FX90
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Johnson Controls Inc. FX80 and FX90; CVE(s): CVE-2025-43867; Summary: The vulnerability is a dependency on a vulnerable third-party component, which could allow an attacker to compromise device configuration files. Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could trigger other CVEs.

item.title: EG4 Electronics EG4 Inverters
item.description: Vulnerable Product: EG4 Electronics Equipment; CVE(s): CVE-2025-52586, CVE-2025-53520, CVE-2025-47872, CVE-2025-46414; Summary: The affected products have multiple vulnerabilities that allow an attacker to intercept and manipulate critical data, install malicious firmware, hijack device access, and gain unauthorized control over the system.

item.title: Yealink IP Phones and RPS (Redirect and Provisioning Service)
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Yealink IP Phones; CVE(s): CVE-2025-52916, CVE-2025-52917, CVE-2025-52918, CVE-2025-52919; Summary: Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could result in information disclosure. The affected products lack serial number verification attempt limits, enabling brute-force enumeration (last five digits). Additionally, the products lack rate limiting, potentially enabling information disclosure via excessive requests, and fail to enforce access restrictions on OpenAPIs for frozen enterprise accounts, allowing unauthorized access to deactivated interfaces. The certificate upload function in the affected products does not properly validate certificate content, potentially allowing invalid certificates to be uploaded.

item.title: Rockwell Automation Arena
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Rockwell Automation Arena; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7025, CVE-2025-7032, CVE-2025-7033; Summary: The vulnerabilities in Rockwell Automation's Arena product are out-of-bounds read, stack-based buffer overflow, and heap-based buffer overflow. Successful exploitation could allow an attacker to disclose information and execute arbitrary code.

item.title: Packet Power EMX and EG
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Packet Power EMX and EGV; CVE(s): CVE-2025-8284; Summary: The missing authentication for the critical function in Packet Power's EMX and EGV products allows attackers to gain full access to the device without authentication, potentially leading to manipulation of monitoring and control functions. Successful exploitation could be done remotely with low attack complexity.

item.title: Here’s how deepfake vishing attacks work, and why they can be hard to detect
item.description: A simulated phishing exercise conducted by Mandiant's security team demonstrated the ease with which AI voice spoofing can facilitate a breach of an organization. The exercise used publicly available voice samples and real-world scenarios, such as a VPN service outage, to convincingly simulate a scenario that elicited immediate action from employees. This highlights the importance of remaining calm and vigilant when receiving unexpected requests or calls, even if they seem urgent or legitimate.

item.title: The AI-Powered Security Shift: What 2025 Is Teaching Us About Cloud Defense
item.description:
The article discusses the importance of artificial intelligence (AI) in cybersecurity, particularly in cloud-native environments. It highlights the need for real-time, context-aware defense and the role AI plays in empowering defenders while creating new attack surfaces. The article also emphasizes the importance of securing AI systems and implementing data guardrails to filter prompts and outputs for sensitive information.
FYSA: The article highlights the evolving threat landscape and the increasing reliance on AI-powered attacks. It notes that attackers are automating faster, using open-source tools to perform reconnaissance, lateral movement, and credential harvesting. The article also emphasizes the importance of runtime visibility and detection in cloud-native environments.

item.title: Microsoft Discloses Exchange Server Flaw Enabling Silent Cloud Access in Hybrid Setups
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Exchange Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53786; Summary: The vulnerability allows an attacker with administrative access to gain elevated privileges in a connected cloud environment without leaving detectable traces. Successful exploitation could enable the attacker to escalate privileges within the organization's connected cloud environment, compromising the identity integrity of the Exchange Online service if left unpatched.

item.title: 6,500 Axis Servers Expose Remoting Protocol; 4,000 in U.S. Vulnerable to Exploits
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Axis Communications; CVE(s): CVE-2025-30023, CVE-2025-30024, CVE-2025-30025, CVE-2025-30026; Summary: Multiple security flaws in video surveillance products from Axis Communications allow for takeover attacks, including pre-authentication remote code execution and authentication bypass. Successful exploitation could grant system-level access and control over cameras within a specific deployment.

item.title: SonicWall Confirms Patched Vulnerability Behind Recent VPN Attacks, Not a Zero-Day
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall; CVE(s): CVE-2024-40766; Summary: The vulnerability, an improper access control issue (CVSS score 9.3), allows malicious actors to gain unauthorized access to SonicWall firewalls with SSL VPN enabled. The spike in activity targeting Gen 7 and newer firewalls is attributed to password reuse and the failure to reset local user passwords after firmware upgrades.

item.title: New Infection Chain and ConfuserEx-Based Obfuscation for DarkCloud Stealer
item.description: The article discusses the evolution of DarkCloud Stealer, a malware family that employs obfuscation techniques and intricate payload structures to evade traditional detection mechanisms. The latest attacks involve an additional infection chain, obfuscation by ConfuserEx, and a final payload written in Visual Basic 6 (VB6).

item.title: Muddled Libra: Why Are We So Obsessed With You?
item.description: The article discusses the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) of a threat group called Muddled Libra, which uses social engineering tactics to target organizations in various industries. The article highlights why Muddled Libra receives more media attention than other similar groups, including their unique vishing playbook and ability to attack companies in waves by industry.

item.title: Researchers Uncover ECScape Flaw in Amazon ECS Enabling Cross-Task Credential Theft
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Amazon Elastic Container Service (ECS); CVE(s): None; Summary: Sweet Security researchers have discovered an "end-to-end privilege escalation chain" in Amazon ECS that allows a malicious container to hijack the IAM privileges of a higher-privileged container on the same EC2 instance, enabling lateral movement, access to sensitive data, and control of the cloud environment.

item.title: Fake VPN and Spam Blocker Apps Tied to VexTrio Used in Ad Fraud, Subscription Scams
item.description: VexTrio Viper is a malicious ad tech purveyor that has been developing fake apps, including VPNs, device "monitoring" apps, RAM cleaners, dating services, and spam blockers. These apps deceive users into signing up for subscriptions, flooding them with ads, and parting with personal information like email addresses.

item.title: Who Got Arrested in the Raid on the XSS Crime Forum?
item.description: A Russian-language cybercrime forum administrator known as Toha has been arrested by Ukrainian authorities, allegedly operating XSS since its inception. The arrest has triggered widespread speculation among forum members about Toha's real identity, with some suggesting it may be a Russian man named Anton Avdeev. However, evidence points to the true identity of the arrested individual being Anton Medvedovskiy, a 38-year-old Ukrainian citizen who owns multiple domains linked to Toha's email address.

item.title: WWBN, MedDream, Eclipse vulnerabilities
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: WWBN AVideo; CVE(s): TALOS-2025-2205, TALOS-2025-2206, TALOS-2025-2207, TALOS-2025-2208, TALOS-2025-2209, TALOS-2025-2212, TALOS-2025-2213; Summary: Five cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities and two vulnerabilities that can lead to arbitrary code execution when chained together. An attacker must get a user to visit a webpage or send a series of specially crafted HTTP requests to trigger these vulnerabilities.
Vulnerable Product: MedDream PACS Premium; CVE(s): TALOS-2025-2154, TALOS-2025-2156, TALOS-2025-2176, TALOS-2025-2177; Summary: Four unique vulnerabilities, including an incorrect default permissions vulnerability, a privilege escalation vulnerability, a reflected XSS vulnerability, and a server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit these vulnerabilities by uploading a malicious file, sending a specially crafted HTTP request, or providing a crafted URL.
Vulnerable Product: Eclipse ThreadX; CVE(s): TALOS-2024-2088; Summary: A buffer overflow vulnerability that can lead to code execution when an attacker sends a sequence of requests.

item.title: CISA Releases Malware Analysis Report Associated with Microsoft SharePoint Vulnerabilities
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49704, CVE-2025-49706, CVE-2025-53770, CVE-2025-53771; Summary: Cyber threat actors chain CVE-2025-49704 and CVE-2025-49706 to gain unauthorized access to on-premises SharePoint servers. The malware steals cryptographic keys and executes a Base64-encoded PowerShell command to fingerprint the host system and exfiltrate data.

item.title: MAR-251132.c1.v1 Exploitation of SharePoint Vulnerabilities
item.description:
FYSA:
The provided articles appear to be analyzing malware and vulnerabilities related to Microsoft SharePoint. The first rule detects .NET DLL payload samples that extract machine key configuration settings within an ASP.NET application's configuration. The second rule detects ToolShell CVE-2025-53770 exploitation of SharePoint servers, including updated IOCs and activity. The third rule is not provided.
The articles are discussing malware and vulnerabilities in Microsoft SharePoint, which could potentially lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, or other security incidents if left unchecked.

item.title: Microsoft Releases Guidance on High-Severity Vulnerability (CVE-2025-53786) in Hybrid Exchange Deployments
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Exchange Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53786; Summary: A high-severity vulnerability in Microsoft Exchange Server allows an attacker with administrative access to escalate privileges and potentially compromise the organization's Exchange Online service. The vulnerability can be exploited by leveraging vulnerable hybrid-joined configurations.

item.title: Akira Exploits SonicWall SSLVPN in Suspected Zero-Day Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall; CVE(s): CVE-2024-40766; Summary: The article discusses a high-severity cyberattack targeting SonicWall's Gen 7 firewall appliances, exploiting what appears to be a zero-day vulnerability in SSLVPN functionality. The attack chain involves initial access, privilege escalation, persistence, lateral movement, credential theft, defense evasion, and payload deployment.

item.title: AI Slashes Workloads for vCISOs by 68% as SMBs Demand More – New Report Reveals
item.description: According to the report, the demand for vCISO (Virtual Chief Information Security Officer) services among SMBs is growing rapidly, with 79% of MSPs and MSSPs reporting high demand. Service providers are scaling up to meet this demand, with adoption increasing by 319% in just one year. The report highlights the benefits of vCISO services, including increased upsell opportunities, improved operating margins, and measurable expansion of the customer base. AI is playing a key role in delivering these services efficiently and profitably.

item.title: Microsoft Launches Project Ire to Autonomously Classify Malware Using AI Tools
item.description: This article is about Microsoft's Project Ire, an autonomous artificial intelligence (AI) agent that can analyze and classify software without assistance to advance malware detection efforts. The system uses specialized tools to reverse engineer software, conducting analysis at various levels, and claims a high accuracy rate in classifying files as malicious or benign.

item.title: When Good Accounts Go Bad: Exploiting Delegated Managed Service Accounts in Active Directory
item.description: This article discusses the BadSuccessor technique, which is an exploit that can be used to escalate privileges in Active Directory on Windows Server 2025. The technique takes advantage of the newly introduced Delegated Managed Service Accounts (dMSAs) and allows an attacker to create a dMSA object and then access specific attributes without requiring legitimate administrative credentials. The article provides an in-depth analysis of the BadSuccessor technique, including its operational footprints, and proposes novel detection strategies to identify such attacks.

item.title: Trend Micro Confirms Active Exploitation of Critical Apex One Flaws in On-Premise Systems
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Trend Micro; CVEs: CVE-2025-54948, CVE-2025-54987; Summary: Trend Micro Apex One Management Console has critical security flaws (command injection and remote code execution) exploited in the wild. The vulnerabilities can be exploited by a pre-authenticated remote attacker to upload malicious code and execute commands on affected installations.

item.title: CERT-UA Warns of HTA-Delivered C# Malware Attacks Using Court Summons Lures
item.description: The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) has warned about cyber attacks carried out by the UAC-0099 threat actor targeting government agencies, defense forces, and enterprises in Ukraine. The attacks use phishing emails to deliver malware families like MATCHBOIL, MATCHWOK, and DRAGSTARE.

item.title: AI Is Transforming Cybersecurity Adversarial Testing - Pentera Founder’s Vision
item.description: The article discusses the future of cybersecurity testing with AI and its potential to revolutionize the field. It presents a vision for Pentera, a company that offers automated penetration testing software, where AI will transform every layer of adversarial testing, making it more conversational, intelligent, and instantly actionable. The article highlights how AI can enhance web attack techniques, make sensitive data discovery and use more precise, and enable language-independent testing. It also describes the role Pentera plays in validating the security of Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI infrastructure, ensuring that organizations can close the gap in their security posture.

item.title: CISA Adds 3 D-Link Vulnerabilities to KEV Catalog Amid Active Exploitation Evidence
item.description: Vulnerable Product: D-Link; CVEs: CVE-2020-25078, CVE-2020-25079, CVE-2020-40799; Summary: Three high-severity vulnerabilities in D-Link Wi-Fi cameras and video recorders were added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog by CISA due to active exploitation. The flaws, from 2020 and 2022, could allow for remote administrator password disclosure, authenticated command injection, and unauthenticated code execution.

item.title: Project AK47: Uncovering a Link to the SharePoint Vulnerability Attacks
item.description: The provided article appears to be an analysis of malicious activities and toolsets used by threat actors, specifically CL-CRI-1040. It discusses the overlap between recent ToolShell exploit activity and the activity of this cluster, which is tracked as CL-CRI-1040.

item.title: Voice phishers strike again, this time hitting Cisco
item.description: FIDO multi-factor authentication (MFA) is a defense mechanism against phishing attacks, as it requires the MFA credential to be physically proximal to the device logging in and binds cryptographic keys to the domain name of the service being logged into. This prevents spoofed or lookalike phishing sites from working.

item.title: ClickFix Malware Campaign Exploits CAPTCHAs to Spread Cross-Platform Infections
item.description: A new social engineering tactic called ClickFix has emerged, which uses propagation methods, narrative sophistication, and evasion techniques to deceive users into infecting their own machines. The tactic involves fake CAPTCHA verification messages guiding victims to execute malicious commands that deploy various types of malware.

item.title: Google’s August Patch Fixes Two Qualcomm Vulnerabilities Exploited in the Wild
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Android; CVE(s): CVE-2025-21479, CVE-2025-27038, CVE-2025-22441, CVE-2025-48530, CVE-2025-48533; Summary: The article discusses multiple security flaws in Android, including two Qualcomm bugs that were actively exploited. The vulnerabilities include an incorrect authorization vulnerability and a use-after-free vulnerability, which could lead to memory corruption and remote code execution.

item.title: Cursor AI Code Editor Vulnerability Enables RCE via Malicious MCP File Swaps Post Approval
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cursor; CVE(s): CVE-2025-54136; Summary: A high-severity security flaw in Cursor's AI-powered code editor allows remote code execution by modifying Model Context Protocol (MCP) server configurations. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-54136, can be exploited to achieve persistent code execution and expose organizations to supply chain risks and data theft.

item.title: ReVault! When your SoC turns against you…
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Broadcom, Dell; CVE(s): CVE-2025-24311, CVE-2025-25050, CVE-2025-25215, CVE-2025-24922, CVE-2025-24919; Summary: The ReVault attack can be used as a post-compromise persistence technique that remains even across Windows reinstalls, and can also bypass Windows Login and/or grant local user Admin/System privileges.

item.title: CISA Adds Three Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
item.description: Vulnerable Product: D-Link DCS-2530L, D-Link DCS-2670L Devices, and D-Link DNR-322L; CVE(s): CVE-2020-25078, CVE-2020-25079, CVE-2022-40799; Summary: The vulnerabilities in these D-Link devices allow for unspecified, command injection, and code download without integrity check, which can be exploited by malicious cyber actors. These types of vulnerabilities pose significant risks to the federal enterprise and should be prioritized for remediation.

item.title: Tigo Energy Cloud Connect Advanced
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Tigo Energy Cloud Connect Advanced; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7768, CVE-2025-7769, CVE-2025-7770; Summary: The Cloud Connect Advanced device contains hard-coded credentials allowing unauthorized access, command injection vulnerability in the /cgi-bin/mobile_api endpoint, and insecure session ID generation. Successful exploitation could lead to unauthorized administrative access, privilege escalation, data exposure, and service disruption.

item.title: CISA Releases Two Industrial Control Systems Advisories
item.description: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) released two Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories on August 5, 2025, providing information about current security issues, vulnerabilities, and exploits affecting ICS products. The advisories encourage users and administrators to review the technical details and mitigations for the affected products.

item.title: Mitsubishi Electric Iconics Digital Solutions Multiple Products
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mitsubishi Electric ICONICS Product Suite and Mitsubishi Electric MC Works64; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7376; Summary: An information tampering vulnerability exists in multiple processes of GENESIS64, MC Works64, and GENESIS due to Windows Shortcut Following (.LNK), allowing an attacker to cause unauthorized writes to arbitrary files on the file system. Successful exploitation could result in a denial-of-service (DoS) condition on the PC if the modified file is necessary for the operation of the PC.

item.title: Misconfigurations Are Not Vulnerabilities: The Costly Confusion Behind Security Risks
item.description: The article highlights the distinction between vulnerabilities and misconfigurations in SaaS environments. It emphasizes that understanding this difference is crucial for securing SaaS platforms, as most incidents are caused by user-controlled settings rather than vendor-provided infrastructure. The article also stresses the importance of posture management and visibility into configurations, permissions, and third-party access to prevent conditions that cause breaches.

item.title: How Top CISOs Save Their SOCs from Alert Chaos to Never Miss Real Incidents
item.description: None. This article is not about a vulnerability but contains cybersecurity-relevant content discussing strategies for improving the efficiency of Security Operations Centers (SOCs), including interactive sandboxes, automation, collaboration, and privacy-first workflows.

item.title: 15,000 Fake TikTok Shop Domains Deliver Malware, Steal Crypto via AI-Driven Scam Campaign
item.description: Vulnerable Product: TikTok Shop; CVE(s): None; Summary: A widespread malicious campaign targeting TikTok Shop users globally aims to steal credentials and distribute trojanized apps. The scam uses phishing, malware, and AI-generated content to trick users into installing a variant of cross-platform malware called SparkKitty that can harvest data from Android and iOS devices.

item.description:

1. Implementing VLAN segmentation with inter-VLAN access controls 2. Deploying firewalls and intrusion prevention systems (IPS) to monitor traffic between IT and OT networks 3. Enhancing authentication and encryption mechanisms

item.description: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) released six Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories on July 24, 2025, providing information about current security issues, vulnerabilities, and exploits surrounding ICS. These advisories are intended for users and administrators to review technical details and mitigations.

item.title: Mitsubishi Electric CNC Series
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mitsubishi Electric CNC Series; CVE(s): CVE-2016-2542; Summary: The vulnerability allows an attacker to execute malicious code by getting setup-launcher to load a malicious DLL due to Uncontrolled Search Path Element (CWE-427). Successful exploitation could lead to the execution of malicious code.

item.title: Network Thermostat X-Series WiFi Thermostats
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Network Thermostat X-Series WiFi thermostats; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6260; Summary: The vulnerable embedded web server allows unauthenticated attackers to gain direct access, reset user credentials, and potentially gain full administrative access. This vulnerability can be exploited remotely with low attack complexity.

item.title: LG Innotek Camera Model LNV5110R
item.description: Vulnerable Product: LG Innotek Camera Model LNV5110R; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7742; Summary: An authentication vulnerability exists in the camera model's firmware, allowing a malicious actor to upload an HTTP POST request to the device's non-volatile storage and potentially gain administrative access. Successful exploitation could lead to remote code execution at the administrator privilege level.

item.title: Honeywell Experion PKS
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Honeywell Experion PKS; CVE(s): CVE-2025-2520, CVE-2025-2521, CVE-2025-2522, CVE-2025-3946, CVE-2025-3947; Summary: The Honeywell Experion PKS contains multiple vulnerabilities including uninitialized variables, memory buffer issues, sensitive information reuse, integer underflows, and wrong handler deployments. Successful exploitation could lead to information exposure, denial of service, or remote code execution.

item.title: Watch This Webinar to Uncover Hidden Flaws in Login, AI, and Digital Trust — and Fix Them
item.description: The article discusses the importance of managing customer logins and data privacy in the era of AI. It highlights the need for organizations to adapt their identity strategies to keep pace with changing user expectations and emerging threats. The webinar "Navigating Customer Identity in the AI Era" offers insights from Auth0's 2025 CIAM Trends Report, providing attendees with practical advice on navigating these challenges.

item.title: SonicWall urges admins to patch critical RCE flaw in SMA 100 devices
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall SMA 100 series appliances; CVE(s): CVE-2025-40599; Summary: The SMA 100 series appliances contain a critical authenticated arbitrary file upload vulnerability that can allow remote threat actors to gain code execution. Attackers need admin privileges to exploit this vulnerability, but SonicWall has not found evidence of active exploitation.

item.title: Pentests once a year? Nope. It’s time to build an offensive SOC
item.description: The article discusses the importance of having an ongoing and dynamic approach to offensive security, rather than relying on periodic pentests or audits. It argues that traditional approaches are insufficient in today's rapidly changing threat landscape and introduces the concept of an "Offensive Security Operations Center" (OSOC) as a solution. The OSOC would continuously validate exposures across prevention, detection, and response layers, using tools such as Breach and Attack Simulation (BAS) and Automated Penetration Testing.

item.title: China-Based APTs Deploy Fake Dalai Lama Apps to Spy on Tibetan Community
item.description: A China-nexus cyber espionage group has been targeting the Tibetan community with two campaigns (Operation GhostChat and Operation PhantomPrayers) ahead of the Dalai Lama's 90th birthday. The attacks use watering hole techniques, compromising legitimate websites and installing backdoors on victim systems to gather sensitive information.

item.title: Researchers Exploit Cursor Background Agents to Take Over Amazon EC2 Instance
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cursor's Background Agents; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article discusses a vulnerability in Cursor's Background Agents that allows unauthorized access to an Amazon EC2 instance. The vulnerability is exploited through the "Show Terminal" button, which provides direct command-line access to the remote infrastructure. The researchers gain root access and can execute commands on the compromised machine, highlighting potential risks for privilege escalation and malicious activities such as cryptocurrency mining or data exfiltration.

item.title: Storm-2603 Exploits SharePoint Flaws to Deploy Warlock Ransomware on Unpatched Systems
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49706, CVE-2025-49704; Summary: The article discusses a vulnerability in on-premises Microsoft SharePoint Server that allows attackers to deploy Warlock ransomware. The attack chain involves exploiting two vulnerabilities (CVE-2025-49706 and CVE-2025-49704) to gain initial access, conduct lateral movement, and ultimately deploy the ransomware.
